ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Oliver, that s great that you were able to start a Ph.D. on this topic.  Where are you doing the Ph.D.?  I look forward to seeing your ideas on evolving

Hi Oliver, that's great that you were able to start a Ph.D. on this topic. =
 Where are you doing the Ph.D.?  I look forward to seeing your ideas on evo=
lving adaptive ANNs, which is clearly essential to the ultimate goals of ne=
uroevolution.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "olivercoleman04" <oliver.=
coleman@...> wrote:
>
> Hi all,
> 
> I've just started a Ph.D. with a topic=
 around neuroevolution, online-learning, adaptive NNs (via synaptic plastic=
ity and/or similar). In my feverish excitement I thought it would be a good=
 idea to start a blog on questions and issues I come across, in the hope th=
at other active researchers will want to comment on and perhaps even start =
a bit of dialogue about them (like this mailing list but more public). I kn=
ow another Ph.D. candidate who keeps a similar blog (totally different rese=
arch area, though) and it's working out great for her, so it didn't seem li=
ke a completely hopeless idea...
> 
> I know some of you are interested in =
the evolution of adaptive NNs, I read your articles as soon as they were po=
sted to this group! :) I also envisage using NEAT and variants in the resea=
rch (I did a study of some of the properties of HyperNEAT for my Honours ye=
ar a year or so ago). It's at http://ojcoleman.com. The first post is mostl=
y background info (I hope I didn't get anything too wrong, let me know if y=
ou think I did!) and what the research is about, but it also explains why I=
 think the proposed approach is a good idea which might provide some good c=
ontroversy points (maybe not so much among this crowd, however).
> 
> I goo=
gled around and couldn't find all that many relevant blogs. Do any of you k=
eep a similar blog or know of any? I could mostly only find generic newsy A=
I ones.
> 
> Cheers,
> Oliver
>
